block.p: Clinton Says Deal Is Near After Meeting With Barak President Clinton met with Prime Minister Ehud Barak in Portugal and later said that a historic peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians was ''within view now.'' He urged both sides to make whatever compromises were needed for an accord and said he was prepared to convene a three-way Camp David-style meeting in Washington.

Missile Defense Criticized President Clinton arrived in Germany for a three-day visit and faced immediate criticism, from Chancellor Gerhard Schroder and others, over United States plans to build a limited missile defense system.

Political Killing Suspected The killing of a top presidential aide in Montenegro was being widely interpreted there as a political attack on the West-leaning government. The timing, just a week ahead of local elections, raised speculation that it was an attempt by Belgrade to destabilize the political process.

Fabrications in German Press Suddeutsche Zeitung of Munich fired two editors of its magazine supplement after it determined that celebrity interviews written by a Swiss journalist in Hollywood had had been fabricated or cobbled together from material published elsewhere.

North Korean Leader in China China and North Korea confirmed that North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, was in Beijing this week for three days of secret meetings. It was the reclusive Mr. Kim's first trip abroad since he succeeded his father in 1994.

High Toll of Japan's Golf Craze Few things reflected Japan's exploding wealth in the 1980's better than its sudden madness for golf. But at least 1,700 golf courses are now either bankrupt or in financial trouble, and lenders who financed the courses are trying to contain one of the economy's biggest problems.

Advance in Treating Strokes Scientists using a new kind of rehabilitation therapy were able to coax the brain into reorganizing its circuitry so that people regained use of partly paralyzed limbs in just two to three weeks, even if the stroke happened years ago.

Court Backs I.N.S. Denial Of Asylum Hearing for Elian A federal appellate panel upheld the right of immigration officials to let Elian Gonzalez's father take the boy back to Cuba, saying the officials have the power to decide that only a parent can act for such a young child in immigration proceedings. But Elian's father was barred from taking his son out of the United States for at least 21 days to give the boy's Miami relatives time to appeal.

Spy-Catcher Post Shelved A plan to create a post giving a senior government official oversight of government efforts to catch spies was set aside largely because of opposition from Attorney General Janet Reno, federal officials said.

Black Agents Claim Intimidation Lawyers for a group of black agents who have filed a racial discrimination suit against the Secret Service asked a Federal judge to stop what they said were efforts by the agency to intimidate their clients.

A Reprieve in Texas Gov. George W. Bush agreed to a 30-day reprieve for a man convicted of raping and killing his stepdaughter, citing concerns that adequate tests on DNA evidence had not been performed. Earlier, a federal appeals court and the United States Supreme Court rejected appeals from the inmate's lawyers.

Bush's Environment Plan Gov. George W. Bush proposed using federal resources and incentives to coax state governments and private citizens into greater conservation efforts, rather than what he said was the Clinton-Gore administration's more forceful approach.
Gore Pledge on Fighting Cancer Vice President Al Gore said he would double federal spending on cancer research and make new cancer treatments and tests available to all Americans who needed them.

Sex Harassment Suit Settled W.R. Grace & Company said it would pay $850,000 to settle a lawsuit in which the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission accused managers at a Maryland food-processing plant of egregious sexual harassment of 22 female workers.

Former Ukraine Leader Indicted Federal officials in San Francisco said former Prime Minister Pavlo Lazarenko, who is seeking political asylum in the United States, had been indicted on money-laundering and conspiracy charges and on 23 counts of transportation of stolen property.

Governors End Standoff Over the Port Authority The governors of New York and New Jersey resolved an 18-month impasse that was blocking Port Authority projects worth billions to both states. A 30-year lease with the Maersk-Sealand shipping line at the Elizabeth Marine Terminal will now be approved. They also agreed to set aside $250 million for New York transportation projects, to open the World Trade Center to private development and to consider raising the $1 PATH commuter rail fare for the first time in 13 years.

A Move Across the River Chase Manhattan, the second-largest bank in the country, is moving thousands of employees from Lower Manhattan to two new office towers at the Newport complex across the Hudson, the latest indication that the Jersey City waterfront has become a corporate haven.

New York Test Scores Improve Officials said fourth graders throughout the state did remarkably better in the second year of a more rigorous reading and writing test, with 59 percent passing, compared with 48 percent in 1999.

Vendors Accused of Price Fixing The Justice Department charged more than a dozen food vendors that supply New York City schools with rigging prices on multimillion-dollar contracts for produce and frozen foods.
An Education Renaissance An annual survey issued by the federal government showed more toddlers in preschool, more high school students going directly to college and more adults returning to class.
Dallas Evens Series, 1-1 The Stars beat the Devils, 2-1, in Game 3 of the four-of-seven-game Stanley Cup finals.
Agassi Out of French Open The top-seeded Andre Agassi, hampered by a foot blisters, lost to Karol Kucera, 2-6, 7-5, 6-1,6-0.
Tito Puente The band leader and percussionist, a key figure in the fusion of Latin music with jazz, was 77.

The eBay Bidding Game An analysis of art auctions on eBay suggests that in addition to people who bid up the price of their own merchandise, there are rings of so-called shill bidders, people who act in partnership by bidding on one another's offerings to drive prices up.

Loophole in Fuel Economy Study A coming government report shows a slight increase in the fuel economy of family vehicles in the 2000 model year. But the rise is mostly because of a loophole that gives carmakers extra mileage credit for vehicles that can run on ethanol, even though virtually no one uses that fuel.

Decline in Auto Sales Auto sales last month were 2 percent below their level in May of last year, the first year-to-year drop since the summer of 1998. Dismal results at DaimlerChrysler and G.M. entirely accounted for the decline, as other manufacturers had record sales.
Fighting Fraud in Investments Federal and state authorities will join forces in fighting fraudulent fixed-rate investment schemes that they say bilk thousands of Americans, especially older people.

Judge Delays Microsoft Ruling The federal judge trying the Microsoft antitrust case unexpectedly agreed to delay his final ruling for about a week, giving the Justice Department time to reply to Microsoft's proposal to water down the government's breakup plan.
